My text:

> I am planning to use Penn EHR (Epic, Clarity) data to look at the impact of a clinical decision support tool (Quality Improvement/Safety Rounding Checklist) used by the four Penn neonatal internsive care units on a variety of clinical outcomes, such as vaccination, metabolic screen ordering, and central line days, among other clinical outcomes. Specifically, would hope to show via regression methods that the use of this tool has led to an improvement in these outcomes.

Two faculty mentors include:

> Leah Carr, MD, Assistant Professor of Clinical Pediatrics, Attending Neonatology and Clinical Informaticist, CHOP/Penn
>
> Christopher Bonafide, MD, MSCE, Associate Professor of Pediatrics, CHOP/Penn

In discussion with my faculty mentors:

> They suggested that I pare down my initial analysis to focus on one outcome as each one would be a hefty analysis. Specifically, after discussion, they recommended that I focus on hepatitis b vaccination rates as something of clinical interest, but also more manageable in the time frame of this project. Specifically, this project will aim to assess the impact of a QI/Safety Rounding Checklist - a clinical decision support tool - implemented across four Penn Medicine NICUs on hepatitis b vaccination rates. This project will use deidentified Penn EHR data (Epic, Clarity) and analysis will be done in aggregate to not reveal local site data.

## Introduction {#sec-introduction}

> There is a well-established body of research associating checklists with improved outcomes, such as improved preferred language documentation.^1-2^ While prior work in the Childrenâ€™s Hospital of Philadelphia NICU has demonstrated success with Epic integration of a checklist, this was limited to a single quaternary academic unit.^3^
>
> In 2019, the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania (HUP) Intensive Care Nursery, a level III NICU in our health system, implemented a REDCap-based checklist to support local quality improvement (QI) and safety initiatives, but compliance with the tool was less than 50%. A 2023 provider survey revealed low perceived relevance and high burden, with key barriers including workflow interruptions and tool accessibility. Feedback strongly supported Epic integration. The same instance of Epic (PennChart) is live in four Penn NICUs. Discussions with leadership of these NICUs revealed strong support for the design and implementation of a standardized network-wide tool, allowing for the development of an Epic-based CDS tool.
>
> In the period of December 2024-March 2025, the four Penn NICUs went live with this tool. Key results from this project include a statistically significant increase in the average biweekly compliance from 25% to 90% from October 2023 to October 2025 based on a statistical process control p-chart at HUP. Across all four NICUs, average compliance was 86% as of October 2025. Survey data (67% response rate,
> 66/98) will also be shared and indicated that most NICU clinicians found the tool easy to use, clinically relevant, and beneficial for patient safety.
>
> While there has been good data to show that such a tool supports clinical processes and workflows both at CHOP and Penn, it is unclear what effect it may have on clinical outcomes of interest. As such, this project will aim to assess the impact of a QI/Safety Rounding Checklist - a clinical decision support tool - implemented across four Penn Medicine NICUs on hepatitis b vaccination rates. This project will use deidentified Penn EHR data (Epic, Clarity) and analysis will be done in aggregate to not reveal local site data.
